image.altText: Papua New Guinea police officers watch on as hundreds of students marched towards the university gate in Port Moresby

props.synopsis: Chiefs and community leaders in Bougainville want an investigation into police officers over their alleged involvement in arming and orchestrating an organised crime gang that targeted people who had travelled to the autonomous region to buy guns and gold.

title.children: Almost a dozen chiefs, leaders allege Bougainville police orchestrated violent robberies of foreigners

image.altText: Ella sitting on the playground.

props.synopsis: Parents with violent children can face a heartbreaking decision: give them up or continue to live in danger. Experts say more needs to be done to help families facing complex situations.

title.children: Ella lives in fear that her son will kill her. She now faces a heartbreaking decision

image.altText: large, thick plume of smoke rises while damaged buildings and rubble can be see in the foreground

props.synopsis: The WHO has expressed concerns about the state of Al-Shifa hospital due to a shortage of supplies and large amount of injured patients unable to receive proper medical care, as separate Israeli attacks kill a French worker in southern Gaza and five Palestinians in the occupied West Bank.

title.children: 'Bloodbath': WHO paints grim picture of Gaza's Al-Shifa hospital

image.altText: A woman smiles.

props.synopsis: The Australian Retailers Association estimates South Australians will spend $4.3 billion this Christmas, defying a national downward trend, but businesses say consumers are being thrifty with their shopping.

title.children: South Australians estimated to defy national spending trend ahead of Christmas

image.altText: A family of four taking a selfie in front of the ocean.

props.synopsis: Some parents are having to fly in carers from interstate due to lack of childcare services in South Australian towns. It comes as research is launched into the depth of the shortfalls.

title.children: Parents fly in family to look after kids due to lack of regional childcare

image.altText: Drone footage shows flooding in Smithfield in Cairns.

props.synopsis: Heavy rain is battering Queensland's far north, causing heavy flooding in low-lying areas as rivers burst their banks in the wake of Tropical Cyclone Jasper.

title.children: Cairns cut off with 'worst flood on record' as mayors call for help from Australian Defence Force

image.altText: The top bit of a submarine in the water next to a large grey ship flying the US flag

props.synopsis: AUKUS documents reveal that WA will have a low-level radioactive waste management system in place as well as receiving an influx of more than 700 Americans to work on the project.

title.children: Over 700 Americans and nuclear waste management — WA AUKUS plans revealed

image.altText: Flooded world showing a Ferris Wheel and a woman in a small boat.

props.synopsis: Video games had a bumper 2023, but the Australian games industry is suffering through one of its worst contractions since the global financial crisis, with lay-offs and studio closures predicted to continue across 2024. What's going on?

title.children: 'Just ruthless': 2023 was a tough year for the Australian video games industry

image.altText: A man with wearing glasses and white top smiling.

props.synopsis: As the grief from Dr Michael Yung's alleged murder continues to ripple through the community, those who helped him establish a charity in honour of his late wife are determined to continue his dream.

title.children: Friend of prominent Adelaide doctor vows to keep charitable legacy alive

image.altText: Christopher Luxon in parliament, pointing and looking quite cross.

props.synopsis: In three weeks, New Zealand's new prime minister has moved to wind back policies designed to improve outcomes for Māori and Pasifika people, and people are taking to the streets.

title.children: 'Not since the early stages of colonisation': How NZ's new PM pried open an old wound

image.altText: A hand holding a $100 note next to a wallet

props.synopsis: Australia's inflation struggle and cost-of-living crisis will be front and centre as 2023 ends and a new one begins, keeping the Reserve Bank back in the national economic driver's seat for another year, writes David Taylor.

title.children: Australia's economic crisis will be front and centre as 2023 ends. But will 2024 be more prosperous?

image.altText: Two women wear traditional Hazara headscarves and clothing.

props.synopsis: Hazara women Zahra Anvari and Gol Nazari settled in Tasmania as refugees seven years ago after decades of persecution. But after a violent incident, the day-to-day fear of discrimination continues.

title.children: Alleged racist attackers try to rip headscarfs from Hobart mother and daughter

image.altText: A crowd of people standing near a beige coloured wall with a collapsed section and yellow tractors in front.

props.synopsis: A 30 metre long section of the massive historic wall collapses during restoration work around the Old City of Kairouan in central Tunisia.

title.children: Ancient wall collapsing kills three at Tunisia UNESCO World Heritage Site

image.altText: hands typing on a laptop

props.synopsis: The new breed of investment and share trading apps targeting retail investors and self-managed super funds are convenient for some but a headache for others, including the corporate regulator, which has found mis-selling, mislabelling, and misleading disclosures, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: A million clients, almost $900b and high-risk assets: The trading wild west on ASIC's radar

image.altText: Putin, wearing a suit, holds a lit thin red candle in front of a mural background

props.synopsis: President Vladimir Putin is formally nominated to run in the 2024 presidential election as an independent with the support of ruling party United Russia.

title.children: With his opposition imprisoned or exiled Putin's supporters rush to nominate him for re-election

image.altText: A dad and his two children, next to an image of a man celebrating

props.synopsis: Nathan Lyon's rise from being a groundsman on $5 an hour to one of the most successful bowlers in Test cricket history is, according to brother Brendan, a "testament" to his dedication and love of the baggy green.

title.children: From a cherry farm to 500 Test wickets, how Nathan Lyon became a great of the game

image.altText: Usman Khawaja walks off with his helmet under one arm and holds up his bat

props.synopsis: Australia's batters had to weather a storm on an uneven pitch before the quicks ripped through the Pakistan line-up to secure a dominant first Test victory. Here are the five quick hits from day four.

title.children: Five quick hits — Perth pitch claims scalps but Khawaja can't be stopped

image.altText: Olivia Colma, Imelda Staunton and Claire Foy in character as differenct versions of Queen Elizabeth II in The Crown

props.synopsis: With the series starting before the Queen's reign,  it forged a reputation of being a prestige drama. But after impressing the critics early on, it seems to have fallen out of favour.

title.children: Did the recent seasons of The Crown feel a bit off to you? It might have something to do with your age

image.altText: a skyline with houses

props.synopsis: What happened to the belief that "housing for all" would be the bedrock of social cohesion?

title.children: What happened to the promise of 'housing for all'?

image.altText: A man, wearing a blue cap with the number 11, at night, with a spotlight on his face.

props.synopsis: Despite being second in the championship, Sergio Perez will be under pressure to perform in 2024 as rumours about his future at Red Bull continue to swirl.

title.children: Sergio Perez under pressure at Red Bull as Daniel Ricciardo rumours swirl

image.altText: A man stands smiling while wearing a hospital gown.

props.synopsis: The 67-year-old has been moved out of the ICU and is walking around after having open heart surgery for a bacterial infection last week.

title.children: Jimmy Barnes up and about as he recovers from open heart surgery

image.altText: A wide shot of a man of Asian descent holding a trophy in front of two computers and a large screen at an e-sports event

props.synopsis: An actuary nicknamed The Annihilator claims a cash prize, trophy, champion's belt and esports glory.

title.children: 'You didn't just succeed — you Exceled': Sydney man wins Microsoft Excel World Championship for third straight year

image.altText: a big ship in the ocean

props.synopsis: The US and British militaries say they have shot down 15 attack drones targeting commercial ships in the Red Sea. Australian peak shipping bodies warn there could be major implications.

title.children: How drone attacks in the Red Sea could cause major disruptions to global trade

image.altText: close up on metallic beetle's head

props.synopsis: In eastern Australia, the arrival of the summer holidays has traditionally been heralded by big iridescent beetles known as Christmas beetles. How many are there this year?

title.children: Are Christmas beetles disappearing? We need your help to find out

image.altText: A boy stands in front of a pile of white goods in a back yard.

props.synopsis: Jack Gower, 10, wants other kids with ADHD to know about his recycling enterprise so he can show them what they can use their extra energy for.

title.children: Boy finds new way to harness excess energy in mission to help other children with ADHD

image.altText: Aerial view of two people eating a parma at a pub.

props.synopsis: A group of graduating uni friends made a plan to stay in touch at regular pub nights, a tradition which has now lasted two decades — helped along by good planning, intergenerational fun and a strict chicken parma rule.

title.children: As people grow older, friendships can drift apart. But this group of former uni mates reckon they've got the solution

image.altText: A child in a santa hat and beard holds a leg of ham half his own body size

props.synopsis: Roads, rates and rubbish are generally the cornerstone of local government, but the Cherbourg Aboriginal Shire Council in Queensland has added ham deliveries to its operations to bring some much-needed cheer.

title.children: Local council gives every household a free leg of ham for Christmas after difficult year
